summary: This document is an email chain between Assistant United States Attorneys discussing a court-ordered declaration to explain disparities in discovery and counsel access between Ghislaine Maxwell (detained at MDC) and Justin Rivera (detained at MCC). The prosecutors are coordinating their response to Judge Engelmayer, who raised concerns about unequal treatment.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Accused co-conspirator of Jeffrey Epstein, detained at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC) in protective custody. The document details the accommodations she receives for discovery review and attorney visits.

persons.name: Justin Rivera
persons.context: Defendant charged in a separate sex trafficking conspiracy case, detained at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in general population. His counsel raised disparities in access compared to Maxwell.

persons.name: Judge Engelmayer
persons.context: Presiding judge in United States v. Rivera et al. He requested a declaration from the BOP to explain the differing accommodations for Maxwell and Rivera, stating the disparity 'jumped off the page' and had 'terrible' optics.

persons.name: Bhaskaran
persons.context: A prosecutor with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York who is coordinating the response to Judge Engelmayer's request and sending the summary email.

connections.description: Both are federal detainees whose access to discovery and counsel accommodations are being compared by the court. They are not co-defendants but are cited in a legal argument about equitable treatment.
Prosecutor is preparing a court-ordered declaration in response to the judge's request to explain disparities in inmate accommodations.

events.title: Declaration Deadline on Access Disparities
events.description: Deadline for the U.S. Attorney's Office to submit a declaration to Judge Engelmayer explaining why discovery and counsel access accommodations for Ghislaine Maxwell cannot be extended to Justin Rivera.

events.title: Judge Engelmayer Raises Disparity Issue
events.description: During a court conference, Judge Engelmayer stated the disparity in accommodations between Maxwell and Rivera 'jumped off the page' and had 'terrible' optics, prompting a request for a formal explanation.

events.title: Scheduled Trial for Justin Rivera
events.description: The expected start date for Justin Rivera's trial on sex trafficking conspiracy charges (note: document says 2020, but context suggests 2021 given email date of 2020).

events.title: Justin Rivera Charged
events.description: Justin Rivera was charged with sex trafficking conspiracy.

events.title: Justin Rivera Detained at MCC
events.description: Justin Rivera began detention at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) on consent while also serving a state sentence.

keyFacts: Prosecutors detail significant disparities in accommodations: Ghislaine Maxwell receives 13 hours/day of electronic discovery access and 15 hours/week of video counsel visits, while Justin Rivera initially received 3 hours/day and 6 hours/week.
The disparities are attributed to Maxwell's unique protective custody housing at MDC versus Rivera's general population housing at MCC, and the greater volume of discovery in Maxwell's case.
Judge Engelmayer raised concerns the disparity had 'terrible' optics and could be perceived as based on race, gender, or class, prompting a formal BOP explanation.
By the date of the email, the MCC had begun leaving a laptop with Rivera all day, ostensibly matching Maxwell's level of electronic discovery access.
The email chain shows coordination among AUSAs to craft a unified legal response addressing treatment disparities between high-profile and other inmates.
